Award.AwardTitle: Collaboratively Developing Research-Based Curricular Materials to Improve Conceptual Understanding in Engineering Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is boosting the dissemination of findings from education research through collaboration of 20 educational researchers and engineering instructors at different colleges and universities in the Pacific Northwest, who are creating and implementing new approaches to teaching the engineering course Mechanics of Materials. Specifically, this project is focusing on deeper understanding of fundamental engineering concepts such as stress, strain, and equilibrium. The collaborators are working to discover and change students' preconceptions, which may be incorrect assumptions of how materials behave, based on their prior coursework and life experience. This project is addressing a real problem that engineering instructors are currently experiencing in their classrooms. Since the engineering educators have been involved in the project from the beginning, they are more likely to continue to use the curriculum materials they develop, and to encourage others to use them. This collaboration is also ensuring that the findings are being implemented in classrooms soon after they are discovered. More interactive, conceptually oriented classrooms, such as those being implemented in this project, will improve student learning and increase student interest and retention in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project is to leverage student misconceptions and faculty experience to improve student understanding of fundamental engineering concepts, in this case mechanics of materials concepts. Engineering concepts are basic ideas that are taught in undergraduate and graduate engineering courses. Example concepts are stress, deformation, or strain when a beam experiences forces due to loads. Concepts are the foundation of engineering curriculum and are typically taught as an expression of a relationship among variables. For example, the concept of stress in a beam is characterized by a well-defined equation relating the beam geometry, the point of interest in the beam, and the location and magnitude of forces applied to the beam. Importantly, in engineering practice, these concepts are used for design and analysis. For example, the choice of the size and material of a beam in a building is related to the concepts of stress, strain, deformation, and many other factors. This research examined how students understand these concepts in a sophomore level engineering course commonly taken by mechanical and civil engineering students. 

To identifty misconceptions, we conducted interviews with engineering students enrolled in mechanics of materials. Interviews revealed two common misconceptions: 1) shear and normal stress depend on the direction the applied load, and 2) shear and normal stress also depend on the location of the applied load. While direction and location of applied loads do influence stress and strain, students often over-simplified this relationship by assuming that stress purely acts at the location and in the direction of the applied load. This, however, is not always true. We demonstrated that even after students are presented with scientific concepts by their instructors, their preconceived notions continue to reinforce misconceptions. These results were interpreted via Stella Vosniadou’s framework theory of conceptual change. This theory argues that people form naïve (i.e., scientifically incorrect) theories to explain physical phenomena in the world based on their experience in everyday life. These findings were instrumental in informing the development of a faculty workshop designed to develop context-specific curricular materials to help students overcome these noted misconceptions.

Faculty development programs for engineering faculty have often taken the form of summer workshops and seminars aimed at disseminating innovative, research-based, pedagogical practices and curricular materials. These programs have increased engineering faculty’s awareness of these innovations and their benefits for student learning, but their adoption into the engineering classroom has been limited for a variety of contextual reasons. Often times engineering faculty are not involved in the development of these innovations or assisted in adopting them during the academic year, limiting the impact and sustainability of such efforts. In response to these issues, we developed a multi-year workshop provide faculty with the tools and resources to collaboratively develop curricular innovations that they would want for their mechanics of materials courses. Engineering faculty were continuously engaged after each workshop and throughout the academic year to aid them with adopting their curriculum and to iteratively improve their curricular innovations based on their experiences in the classroom. 

Based on the findings from this research and experiences in the workshops, engineering education researchers and practitioners have iteratively and collaboratively developed innovative curricular approaches to enhance student engagement and understanding around common misconceptions in mechanics of materials. These tools include physically deformable models, novel conceptual explanations, and alternative conceptual assessments. Engineering faculty were provided sustained facilitation over multiple years while using this innovative curriculum to iteratively improve its adoptability and to understand how curriculum development and adoption can be more attunded to the needs of individual engineering faculty. Interviews with the participating engineering faculty throughout the academic year revealed that 1) faculty felt empowered by their increased role in the curriculum development process empowering and 2) sustained support helped hold them accountable to adopting their curricular innovations. Both of these findings indicate that adoption of better pedagogical practices into the engineering classroom can be enhanced by giving faculty a greater role in their own faculty development. The participating engineering faculty also found that focusing our summer workshop on one course, in this case mechanics of materials, was greatly beneficial to their professional development. Most notably, there was significant interest in future similar faculty development programs for other fundamental engineering courses.

These findings indicate that pedagogical strategies developed by educational researchers can be more focused and optimized towards specific engineering courses and concepts to make them more applicable to engineering faculty; as opposed to previous attempts at broad dissemination that have been limited in their impact. This can be done by providing engineering faculty with greater involvement in the development of curricular innovations, greater autonomy in their adoption decisions, and investing the resources necessary to support faculty throughout the academic year.
